title: Results
text: This section answers RQ1‚ÄìRQ3 and evaluates H1‚ÄìH3 using the final E2SFCA accessibility surfaces, the Medicaid equity gap, and the priority-based siting logic.

title: Results
text:
3.1 The Medicaid equity gap (RQ2, H2)





The map shows percentage accessibility loss when the network is restricted to Medicaid-accepting facilities only. Darker reds represent tracts where a large share of E2SFCA access is lost due to insurance acceptance constraints.
Key patterns: - High loss appears in Southwest, Lower North, and river-ward Philadelphia. - Many high-SVI tracts fall in upper loss classes, consistent with H2. - Tracts near Center City and major campuses retain more access even under Medicaid constraints.

title: Results
text:
3.2 Neighborhood typologies (RQ2, H1)





The scatter summarises KMeans typologies using tract-level SVI and Medicaid-constrained E2SFCA:

Privileged, low SVI and high access
Supported but vulnerable, high SVI and high access
Moderate access, high SVI and mid access
Critical deserts, high SVI and low access

The weak global relationship between SVI and accessibility supports H1, differences are shaped by capacity and insurance acceptance, not only distance.

title: Results
section: 3.3 Priority index and site recommendations (RQ3, H3)
text:
3.3 Priority index and site recommendations (RQ3, H3)
The project defines a Priority Index:
\[
\text{Priority Index} = \text{Normalized Equity Gap} \times \text{Normalized SVI}
\]
High values indicate vulnerable areas losing significant access under Medicaid constraints. This surface guides site recommendations and scenario-based prioritisation.

title: Results
text:
3.4 Future directions
Core: - Level 2 (E2SFCA) for spatial accessibility - Level 4 (SVI + Medicaid) for equity
Baselines: - Level 1 distance and p median thinking to debunk the distance myth
Extensions: - Light Level 3 MCLP-style scenario - Level 5 predictive ideas as future work

title: Results
text:
3.5 Conclusions

High SVI areas suffer both from risk exposure and lack of accessible care.
Policy interventions must target medical deserts and incentivise Medicaid acceptance.
Future research should integrate multimodal networks and dynamic capacity.

title: Results
text:
3.6 Limitations

Temporal bias, free-flow travel times ignore congestion.
Single mode, transit and walking are not yet included.
Capacity proxy, beds approximate capacity, appointment data unavailable.
Insurance modelling, Medicaid treated as binary acceptance flag rather than a capacity share.
Remaining uncertainty, edge cross-state referral patterns are simplified.

title: Data & Methods
text:
The supply table lists all datasets that describe where care is provided:

Hospitals and acute-care facilities. Core supply points, merged from OpenDataPhilly, state health agencies, CMS and OpenStreetMap, then de-duplicated by name and address.
City and community health centers. Safety-net providers scraped from the Philadelphia Department of Public Health website to fill gaps in official open data.
Buffer-area hospitals. Facilities in surrounding counties that fall within the network catchment of Philadelphia tracts, these are essential for correcting edge effects.
Hospital bed capacity. Used as a proxy for acute-care capacity when computing supply-to-demand ratios in the E2SFCA model.









Demand-side datasets describe who needs care and how vulnerable they are:

Total population by tract (ACS 2021). Pulled via the U.S. Census API and used as baseline demand in all accessibility calculations.
Social Vulnerability Index (SVI, CDC ATSDR). A tract-level composite index in the range 0‚Äì1 capturing socioeconomic status, minority status, housing and transportation vulnerability.
Medicaid share. Derived from ACS insurance tables and used to approximate the share of residents relying on public insurance.
WorldPop population grid. A high-resolution raster downloaded manually from WorldPop.org and used to cross-check ACS population counts through zonal statistics.









Spatial and network layers provide the geographic backbone for the model:

Census tract boundaries, including neighbors. TIGER/Line shapefiles, downloaded and processed programmatically, with an extended region covering neighboring counties for edge-effect correction.
Road network (driving graph). A drivable street network extracted from OpenStreetMap via OSMnx, including speed estimates and travel times.
Travel-time OD matrix (minutes). Origin‚Äìdestination travel times in minutes between tract centroids and facilities, computed on the OSMnx graph.
HUD Qualified Census Tracts (QCT). Additional vulnerability layer to identify historically disadvantaged tracts.
City and county boundary. Used only for cartographic masking, to avoid artificially truncating catchments at the study-area border.

title: Data & Methods
text:
The supply table lists all datasets that describe where care is provided:

Hospitals and acute-care facilities. Core supply points, merged from OpenDataPhilly, state health agencies, CMS and OpenStreetMap, then de-duplicated by name and address.
City and community health centers. Safety-net providers scraped from the Philadelphia Department of Public Health website to fill gaps in official open data.
Buffer-area hospitals. Facilities in surrounding counties that fall within the network catchment of Philadelphia tracts, these are essential for correcting edge effects.
Hospital bed capacity. Used as a proxy for acute-care capacity when computing supply-to-demand ratios in the E2SFCA model.









Demand-side datasets describe who needs care and how vulnerable they are:

Total population by tract (ACS 2021). Pulled via the U.S. Census API and used as baseline demand in all accessibility calculations.
Social Vulnerability Index (SVI, CDC ATSDR). A tract-level composite index in the range 0‚Äì1 capturing socioeconomic status, minority status, housing and transportation vulnerability.
Medicaid share. Derived from ACS insurance tables and used to approximate the share of residents relying on public insurance.
WorldPop population grid. A high-resolution raster downloaded manually from WorldPop.org and used to cross-check ACS population counts through zonal statistics.









Spatial and network layers provide the geographic backbone for the model:

Census tract boundaries, including neighbors. TIGER/Line shapefiles, downloaded and processed programmatically, with an extended region covering neighboring counties for edge-effect correction.
Road network (driving graph). A drivable street network extracted from OpenStreetMap via OSMnx, including speed estimates and travel times.
Travel-time OD matrix (minutes). Origin‚Äìdestination travel times in minutes between tract centroids and facilities, computed on the OSMnx graph.
HUD Qualified Census Tracts (QCT). Additional vulnerability layer to identify historically disadvantaged tracts.
City and county boundary. Used only for cartographic masking, to avoid artificially truncating catchments at the study-area border.

title: Data & Methods
text:
1.4 Data acquisition methods
(a) APIs and web services

U.S. Census Bureau API. requests is used to download ACS 2021 5-year estimates for population and Medicaid-related insurance variables at the tract level.
ArcGIS REST API (HUD QCT). Qualified Census Tracts are queried directly as GeoJSON, filtered to the extended Philadelphia region, and saved to disk for reproducibility.
Nominatim geocoding API. Geocodes scraped health center addresses into coordinates using geopy, then projected and snapped to the street network.

(b) Web scraping

BeautifulSoup scraper for city health centers. Some safety-net facilities are only listed on an HTML page, a small script parses the table, standardizes addresses, and writes a clean CSV before geocoding.

(c) Specialized Python libraries

OSMnx. Downloads the drivable road network, adds edge speeds and travel times, and provides nearest-node mapping from centroids and facilities to the graph.
GeoPandas and Rasterio. Used to read shapefiles, project geometries, and perform zonal statistics on the WorldPop raster to validate ACS populations.

(d) Static archives and manual downloads

WorldPop raster (usa_pop_2020...tif). Downloaded manually from WorldPop.org, stored under data/raw/, read inside a helper function (process_worldpop_raster). There is no download script in this repository.
CDC SVI CSV (philly_svi_2020.csv). Downloaded manually from CDC/ATSDR, then read via pd.read_csv(DATA_RAW / "philly_svi_2020.csv").

title: Data & Methods
text:
1.5 Reproducible acquisition snippets






NoteACS and Medicaid via Census API





```python import requests import pandas as pd
CENSUS_API_KEY = ‚ÄúYOUR_KEY_HERE‚Äù BASE_URL = ‚Äúhttps://api.census.gov/data/2021/acs/acs5‚Äù VARS = [‚ÄúB01003_001E‚Äù, ‚ÄúC27012_004E‚Äù]
params = { ‚Äúget‚Äù: ‚Äú,‚Äù.join([‚ÄúNAME‚Äù] + VARS), ‚Äúfor‚Äù: ‚Äútract:*‚Äú,‚Äùin‚Äù: ‚Äústate:42 county:101‚Äù, ‚Äúkey‚Äù: CENSUS_API_KEY, }
r = requests.get(BASE_URL, params=params) r.raise_for_status() data = r.json()
acs_df = pd.DataFrame(data[1:], columns=data[0]) acs_df[‚ÄúGEOID‚Äù] = acs_df[‚Äústate‚Äù] + acs_df[‚Äúcounty‚Äù] + acs_df[‚Äútract‚Äù] acs_df = acs_df.drop(columns=[‚Äústate‚Äù, ‚Äúcounty‚Äù, ‚Äútract‚Äù])









Note





OSMnx network and travel-time matrix import osmnx as ox
place_name = ‚ÄúPhiladelphia, Pennsylvania, USA‚Äù G = ox.graph_from_place(place_name, network_type=‚Äúdrive‚Äù, buffer_dist=15000)
G_speed = ox.add_edge_speeds(G) G_tt = ox.add_edge_travel_times(G_speed)




Methods 2.1 Preprocessing and integration

Cleaning and standardising IDs. All tract-level datasets (ACS, SVI, QCT) are keyed by GEOID, facility datasets are keyed by stable identifiers. Duplicates and obvious geocoding errors are removed.
Merging supply layers. Hospitals, buffer-area hospitals, and community health centers are merged into a unified facility layer with type, Medicaid acceptance, and bed capacity.
Validating population counts. WorldPop raster counts are aggregated to tracts and compared to ACS totals, ACS remains the authoritative source in the final model.
Constructing vulnerability and insurance indicators. SVI (RPL_THEMES) is cleaned and re-scaled to 0‚Äì1, Medicaid share is derived from ACS insurance tables.
2.2 Network analysis and accessibility modelling 2.2.1 Analytical pipeline
{fig-align=‚Äúcenter‚Äù width=980}
The pipeline summarises the analytical flow:
Data collection via APIs, scraping and manual downloads.
Preprocessing and integration of supply, demand and vulnerability data.
Network analysis and E2SFCA on an OSMnx driving graph to compute accessibility metrics.
Clustering and dashboarding to turn indicators into typologies and interactive exploration tools.
2.2.2 Accessibility paradox framing
{fig-align=‚Äúcenter‚Äù width=980}
This figure frames the ‚ÄúPhiladelphia Paradox‚Äù, high-profile medical supply can coexist with large neighborhood inequities once capacity, competition, insurance acceptance, and vulnerability are considered jointly.
2.2.3 Baseline drive time and the edge-effect problem
{fig-align=‚Äúcenter‚Äù width=980}
Baseline nearest-provider drive time computed only from facilities inside Philadelphia can create boundary-shaped artifacts, facilities just outside the city are ignored.
2.2.4 Edge-effect correction
{fig-align=‚Äúcenter‚Äù width=980}
To correct edge effects, the model uses an expanded bounding box, merges surrounding-area facilities, and recomputes OD travel times on the buffered network.
2.3 E2SFCA accessibility with Gaussian decay
The Enhanced Two-Step Floating Catchment Area (E2SFCA) model is implemented as the core accessibility metric:
Step 1, facility catchment ratios
ùëÖ ùëó = ùëÜ ùëó / ‚àë ùëñ ùê∑ ùëñ ùë§ ( ùëë ùëñ ùëó ) R j ‚Äã
=S j ‚Äã
/‚àë i ‚Äã
D i ‚Äã
w(d ij ‚Äã
)
Step 2, tract accessibility scores
ùê¥ ùëñ = ‚àë ùëó ùëÖ ùëó ùë§ ( ùëë ùëñ ùëó ) A i ‚Äã
=‚àë j ‚Äã
R j ‚Äã
w(d ij ‚Äã
)
The model is run twice, all facilities (access_all) and Medicaid-accepting only (Access_Score). Equity_Gap measures percentage loss under Medicaid constraints, Weighted_Impact combines Equity_Gap with SVI.
2.4 Machine learning clustering and neighborhood typologies
{fig-align=‚Äúcenter‚Äù width=980}
Using KMeans from scikit-learn, the project performs unsupervised clustering on tract-level indicators (SVI, Medicaid E2SFCA, optionally Equity_Gap). Features are standardised, a four-cluster solution balances interpretability and within-cluster variance. The typologies connect directly to Priority Index and site recommendations in Results.

title: Dashboard
text: This page embeds the Panel dashboard exported from Python.

title: Dashboard
text: This page embeds the Panel dashboard exported from Python.

title: About
text:
Author: Haolong Chen
Program: Master of City Planning, Smart Cities concentration
Institution: University of Pennsylvania
This site is the final project for MUSA 5500 and also forms the empirical core of a broader thesis on healthcare accessibility and equity in Philadelphia.

title: About
text:
Purpose
The project demonstrates how network-based accessibility models and equity metrics can be combined to diagnose where acute-care access is structurally limited, quantify the Medicaid equity gap, and propose priority locations for new or expanded facilities.

title: About
text:
Technical stack
Python libraries, GeoPandas, Pandas, NumPy, OSMnx, NetworkX, Rasterio, scikit-learn, hvPlot, Holoviews, Panel.
Visualization, Bokeh tiles and Carto basemaps for web-native maps.
Deployment, Panel exported HTML embedded into a Quarto multi-page website, served via GitHub Pages.

title: About
text:
Disclaimer
This is a student research project, not an official product of the City of Philadelphia, the University of Pennsylvania, or any healthcare provider.

title: Project Overview
text: This final project for MUSA 5500 Geospatial Data Science in Python uses Philadelphia as a case study to examine how spatial accessibility to acute care changes once we move beyond simple distance and incorporate capacity, insurance acceptance, and social vulnerability.

title: Project Overview
text:
Research questions
RQ1 (Diagnosis): How does spatial accessibility to acute healthcare facilities vary across Philadelphia when measured using a realistic road network and an E2SFCA travel time model under free flow conditions? (Addressed by Levels 1 and 2.)
RQ2 (Equity): Is this accessibility equitably distributed, or does it systematically disadvantage socially vulnerable groups? (Addressed by Level 4.)
RQ3 (Intervention): Where should new facilities be located to maximize impact for the most vulnerable? (Addressed by Level 3 logic.)

title: Project Overview
text:
Hypotheses
H1 [Beyond distance]. Even when realistic road network travel times are used, variations in spatial accessibility will not be primarily driven by physical distance to hospitals, but by capacity constraints and spatial mismatches between supply and demand.
H2 [The Medicaid gap]. Vulnerable populations will face a significant accessibility penalty when limited to Medicaid accepting facilities, confirming structural inequity.
H3 [Targeted optimization]. Siting new facilities based on a multi criteria ‚ÄúGap Index‚Äù that combines population with SVI will be more effective than traditional density based planning.

title: Project Overview
text:
Five analytical levels
Level 1, naive distance and p median
Method, Euclidean distance or shortest path travel time and a simple p median allocation.
Role, Baseline that illustrates the ‚Äúdistance myth‚Äù, physical proximity alone does not guarantee real access because capacity is ignored.
Level 2, interaction via E2SFCA
Method, Enhanced Two Step Floating Catchment Area with Gaussian distance decay.
Role, Core engine that quantifies accessibility as a capacity adjusted ratio on the road network, integrating supply and demand within realistic catchments.
Level 3, optimization and gap logic
Method, Light demand gap index and simple maximal coverage reasoning, selecting a small set of candidate sites.
Role, Scenario tool that tests how three to five new facilities under a budget constraint could shift access for high priority tracts.
Level 4, equity integration
Method, Social Vulnerability Index and Medicaid only filtering applied to Level 2 scores.
Role, Turns accessibility into a distributive justice question, asking who loses how much access and where vulnerable groups are systematically penalized.
Level 5, emerging AI and robustness
Method, Predictive machine learning and simple stochastic surge models.
Role, Frames a longer term research agenda that can predict hidden demand and stress test the system under future shocks, beyond the scope of a single masters thesis.

title: Project Overview
text:
Position of the current work
Core of the thesis

Level 2 [E2SFCA] provides the minimum scientifically credible measure of spatial accessibility.
Level 4 [equity integration with SVI and Medicaid] translates accessibility into explicit distributive justice questions, connecting the model to planning practice.

Baseline and teaching tools

Level 1 [naive distance and p median] serves as a baseline that demonstrates the ‚Äúdistance myth‚Äù. It is valuable for teaching and communication, but it is not sufficient for serious policy guidance.

Optional extensions

Level 3 [a light MCLP style siting of three to five facilities] is implemented as scenario analysis. It helps explore intervention options, but it is not required to answer the core diagnostic and equity questions.
Level 5 [predictive or robust optimization] is outlined as future work, for example using machine learning to infer hidden demand or simple stochastic models of surge events.

Message for the committee
Levels 2 and 4 form the smallest, necessary combination that fully answers RQ1 and RQ2 for this thesis.
Level 1 anchors the analysis in intuitive baselines, while Levels 3 and 5 define a realistic longer term research agenda that can be pursued beyond this project.

title: References
text: The full thesis engages with over 200 academic and policy sources. Below are the core methodological references that anchor the models and interpretations shown in this site.

title: References
text:
Key methodological references

CDC. (2020). Delay or Avoidance of Medical Care Because of COVID-19‚ÄìRelated Concerns. MMWR Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.
Luo, W., & Qi, Y. (2009). An enhanced two-step floating catchment area (E2SFCA) method. Health & Place.
Wang, F. (2012). Measurement, optimization, and impact of health care accessibility: A methodological review. Annals of the AAG.
Planey, A. M., et al.¬†(2022). Locating equity: Spatial access and health equity analysis of the Medicaid-accepting safety-net. Social Science & Medicine.
Roy, A., & Kar, B. (2022). A multicriteria decision analysis framework to measure equitable healthcare access during COVID-19.
Faraji-Najarkolaie, F., et al.¬†(2022). Expanding vulnerability indices for pandemic effects. Journal of Transport & Health.

Etc, additional sources are cited in the written paper but omitted here for brevity.

title: References
text:
Data sources

U.S. Census Bureau, ACS 5-year estimates (2021)
CDC / ATSDR Social Vulnerability Index (SVI)
OpenDataPhilly and state health sources for hospitals
City of Philadelphia and health department pages for community health centers
